intro: Corydalis rutifolia var. subuniflora, commonly known as the narrowleaf corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink to purple, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its root system consists of delicate, fibrous roots that are often used in traditional herbal medicine. Corydalis rutifolia var. subuniflora thrives in moist, well-drained soils and partial to full shade, making it a suitable candidate for woodland gardens.
